review.title: A Theory of Local Matching: SIFT and Beyond
review.abstract: Why has SIFT been so successful? Why its extension, DSP-SIFT, can further improve SIFT? Is there a theory that can explain both? How can such theory benefit real applications? Can it suggest new algorithms with reduced computational complexity or new descriptors with better accuracy for matching? We construct a general theory of local descriptors for visual matching. Our theory relies on concepts in energy minimization and heat diffusion. We show that SIFT and DSP-SIFT approximate the solution the theory suggests. In particular, DSP-SIFT gives a better approximation to the theoretical solution; justifying why DSP-SIFT outperforms SIFT. Using the developed theory, we derive new descriptors that have fewer parameters and are potentially better in handling affine deformations.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Questions: Why was SIFT so successful? Why can DSP-SIFT [Dong and Soatto, 2015] continue to improve SIFT? Is there a theory that can explain both? How can such a theory benefit real applications? Can it propose new algorithms with reduced computational complexity or new descriptors with better accuracy for matching? Submissions: We construct a general theory of local descriptors for visual matching. Our theory is based on concepts for energy minimization and heat transfer. We show that SIFT and DSP-SIFT approach the solution that the theory suggests. DSP-SIFT in particular offers a better approximation to the theoretical solution; a justification for why DSP-SIFT performs better than SIFT. We derive new algorithms based on this theory. In particular, we present a computationally efficient approach to DSP-SIFT algorithm [Dong and Soatto, 2015, by directly replacing the Sampling process with DSP-SIv].
